headline: Scientists discover time travel may be possible - and already happening | indy100
context: The notion of time travel has fascinated humans for thousands of years, but it’s always been a work of fiction – until now.

Scientists have discovered evidence of time travel for real, albeit at a microscopic level. Till Bohmer and Thomas Blochowicz are the lead authors of a new study, Time reversibility during the ageing of materials, which is published in Nature Physics.

annotations.paragraph: The research from the two researchers at the Technical University of Darmstadt in Germany focuses on time effectively ‘shuffling’ in the structure of certain materials like glass.
annotations.reason: Introduces the specific focus of the research related to time travel.

annotations.paragraph: It turns out that time doesn’t behave in an exactly linear manner. The study looked into how the composition of materials changes over time.
annotations.reason: Provides insight into the study's findings about time's behavior.

annotations.paragraph: Glass features one of the most fascinating structures of all the items humans use every day.
annotations.reason: General statement about glass that does not contribute to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Instead of following more traditional molecular structures, glass molecules actually constantly fall into new places. As such, glass is constantly reversing time on a molecular level.
annotations.reason: Explains how glass molecules relate to the concept of time reversal.

annotations.paragraph: To test this idea, glass structures were watched using scattered laser light. They observed the glass samples pushing and reforming into new arrangements.
annotations.reason: Describes the method used to observe the time-reversing behavior in glass.

annotations.paragraph: "The minuscule fluctuations in the molecules had to be documented using an ultra-sensitive video camera. "You can't just watch the molecules jiggle around," said Professor Blochowicz.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about the scientific method used in the study.

annotations.paragraph: Because of the way glass moves around internally like this, it’s not possible for scientists to say whether the changes are happening forwards or backwards.
annotations.reason: Explains a key finding related to the study's observations on time reversibility.

annotations.paragraph: It’s a fascinating thought – and while it won’t make humans any closer to being able to travel in time, it’ll certainly change the way we all think about certain materials we use every day.
annotations.reason: Provides a generalization without adding new information to the core story.

annotations.paragraph: It comes after scientists have released a new study which could change our understanding of what could be theoretically possible regarding time travel in 2023.
annotations.reason: Mentions the study's potential impact on theoretical understanding, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: In essence, the research rules out the concept of every being able to head back in time. The study has stated that time in the universe can only go one way – and it’s all thanks to a new study into light and its relationship with other objects.
annotations.reason: Summarizes a significant conclusion of the study, directly related to the headline.
